P  The United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity identifies ecosystem fragmentation as a key driver of loss of 

global biodiversity and associated ecosystem services. 

P  Biodiversity corridors are geographic areas within or cutting across GMS economic corridors that need to be placed 
under  sustainable  management  regimes  to  secure  local  livelihoods,  address  habitat  fragmentation,  and  maintain 
ecosystem services. They ensure the continuity of ecological processes between natural protected areas.

conservation  of  transboundary  landscapes.  It  could  serve  as  a  funding  bridge  to  Reduced  Emissions  from 
Deforestation  and  Forest  Degradation  and  Conservation  and  Enhancement  of  Carbon  Stocks  (REDD/REDD+)

Policy  and  sectoral  relevance.  The  project  is  in  line  with  the  GMS  10-year  (2002–
6. 
2012) strategic framework thrust: protecting the environment and promoting sustainable use of 
shared  natural  resources.  The  project  will  contribute  to  pillar  4  of  ADB's  regional  cooperation 
and integration strategy: cooperation in regional public goods. The project will also support the 
new  GMS  strategic  framework  (2012–2022),  currently  being  prepared,  and  the  process  of 
transitioning  from  GMS  transport  corridors  into  full-fledged  economic  corridors.  Sustainable 
environmental management is a critical aspect of the poverty reduction strategies in Cambodia, 
the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam, with more than two-thirds of the population directly deriving their 
sustenance  from  natural  resources  and  agricultural  sectors.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the 
targets of the National Strategic Development Plan Update 2009–2013 of Cambodia; the draft 
VII National Socio Economic Development Plan 2011–2015 of the Lao PDR; and Article 9 of the 
recently  approved  Biodiversity  Law  (Law  No.  20/2008/QH12),  the  Forestry  Development 
Strategy  to  2020  (Prime  Minister  Decision  No.  18/2007/QD-TTg,  5  February  2007),  and  the 
overall socioeconomic development objectives of Viet Nam for 2011–2015.

10. 
Output  1:  Institutions  and  communities  strengthened  for  biodiversity  corridor 
management. Investments under this output will focus on (i) strengthening the capacity of the 
national,  provincial,  district,  and  commune  bodies  for  corridor  planning  and  management;  and 
(ii)  providing  protection  and  sustainable  use  policies,  guidelines,  and/or  local  regulations  for 
enforcing  biodiversity  corridor  management  plans.  In  particular,  activities  will  contribute  to  
(i) management plans and corridor policy and legal framework covering around 1.93 million ha 
of forest and nonforest land in 56 communes and 69 villages spread across Cambodia, the Lao 
PDR, and Viet Nam; and (ii) participatory land use maps and commune and village investment 
plans  with  delineation  and  demarcation  of  permanent  forest  boundaries  and  provision  of  new 
land use certificates.  
 
11. 
Output  2:  Biodiversity  corridors  restored,  protected,  and  maintained. The focus is 
on  commune  and  village-based  forest  protection  and  restoration.  The  bulk  of  the  investments 
under  output  2  will  target  forest  restoration,  covering  19,200  ha  in  the  form  of  natural  forest 
replanting, enrichment planting, NTFP planting, and agroforestry. Restoration activities include 
labor inputs provided by women on a cash basis, thus improving household incomes. Activities 
to identify viable reduced emissions from deforestation and forest degradation and conservation 
and  enhancement  of  carbon  stocks  (REDD/REDD+)  pilot  sites  will  enable  the  project  to 
leverage incremental funding for forest protection and restoration (an additional 16,100 ha) from 
funds  specifically  set  up  to  promote  REDD.  The  commune  and  village  development  fund 
mechanism will be used as a decentralized local instrument to receive REDD funding for carbon 
sequestration.  The  project  will  also  assist  the  selected  districts  in  the  provinces  to  establish 
inventory  sample  plots,  conduct  biodiversity  surveys,  and  draft  village/commune  forest 
management plans. 
 
12. 
Output  3:  Livelihoods  improved  and  small-scale  infrastructure  support  provided. 
Demand-driven  livelihood  and  small-scale  infrastructure  subprojects  prioritized  in  participatory 
consultations at the start of project will be identified and undergo a rigorous screening process. 
Each  selected  commune  has  a  block  allocation  for  livelihood  improvements  comprising  NTFP 
production and processing, home gardens, livestock farming and other interventions selected by 
beneficiaries. Some of these livelihood options can also be pursued through the mechanism of 
the  commune  and  village  development  funds,  which  will  provide  microfinancing  facilities  to 
households  to  borrow  for  their  projects  of  choice.  At  least  4,775  households  and  more  than 
4,000  farmers  will  receive  technical  and  cash  support  for  livelihood  and  productivity 
enhancement.  In  addition  to  livelihood  interventions,  the  selected  communes  and  villages  will 
receive small-scale infrastructure support ($100,000 per village in the Lao PDR, $150,000 per 
commune  in  Cambodia,  and  $235,000  per  commune  in  Viet  Nam).  Small-scale  infrastructure 
support will primarily focus on (i) commune-based potable water schemes; (ii) provision of waste 
management  and  sanitation  facilitations;  and  (iii)  improvement  and  upgrading  of  rural  access 
roads  from  communes  to  markets.  Special  attention  will  be  given  to  ensure  that  the  poor  and 
ethnic minority groups participate equitably in subproject benefits.  
 
13. 
Output  4:  Project  management  and  support  services  operationalized.  The  project 
will  resource  the  management  structures  for  a  sector-like  project  that  is  supervised  by  the 
executing  agencies  in  capital  cities  but  implemented  from  provincially  based  provincial  project 
management  units  (PPMUs)  and  provincial  project  offices  (PPOs).  The  central  project 
coordination  units  (CPCUs),  central  project  management  units  (CPMUs),  and  national  project 
management  units  (NPMUs)  will  coordinate  (i)  consultant recruitment  and  supervision;  and  (ii) 
procurement  of  materials,  equipment,  and  vehicles  during  project  implementation.  Feasibility 
studies,  and  design  and  implementation  of  subprojects  will  be  coordinated  and  supervised  by 
the  PPMUs  and  PPOs.  Geographic  information  system  (GIS)-based  databases  will  be

Project  preparation  and  implementation  for  reforestation  and  restoration  will  (i)  ensure 
that  appropriate  species  are  chosen  for  specific  sites  to  optimize  production,  and  (ii)  improve 
and  protect  the  environment.  Most  of  the  livelihood  interventions  (agroforestry,  NTFP,

can  be  easily  procured  through  short-term  consultancy  inputs  and  other  extension  services 
within  the  target  countries.  Small-scale  infrastructure  priorities  indicated  by  the  beneficiaries 
revolve  around  water  wells  or  potable  water  schemes,  provision  of  latrines,  and  repair  or 
rehabilitation of rural access roads. Due to the mountainous terrain, greater attention to design 
and implementation quality will be needed. The focus of the civil works implementation will be 
on quality rather than maximizing coverage, and designs will be based on appropriate standards 
to ensure sustainability.

B. 
 
20. 
The economic viability of proposed interventions was assessed by adopting appropriate 
models  applicable  for  the  region.  The  project  is  expected  to  yield  major  benefits,  including  
(i)  incremental  employment  for  households  and  local  communities  generated  from  proposed 
investments  for  boundary  surveys,  demarcation,  inventories,  and  reforestation,  that  in  turn  will 
provide  incentives  to  engage  in  corridor  planning  and  management  activities;  (ii)  improved 
livelihoods  through  innovative  mechanisms  to  engage  local  communities  in  conservation  and 
provision  of  essential  rural  infrastructure  facilities;  (iii)  access  to  safe  drinking  water  and 
avoidance  of  significant  water-related  diseases  and  health-care  related  costs;  and  (iv)  public 
and  private  utilities,  enterprises,  and  downstream  farmers  benefiting  from  the  enhanced 
ecosystem services generated through the action of direct beneficiaries. The value of improved 
landscape  management  will  include  gains  from  increased  carbon  sequestration  and  resultant 
emission  reductions;  expanded  ecotourism  potential;  and  losses  avoided  from  flood  damage, 
extreme  weather  events,  saltwater  inundation  of  coastal  aquifers,  and  costs  associated  with 
reduced and irregular river flow. The project is expected to generate social benefits that accrue 
to communities, local government units, and private and nongovernment organizations through 
stakeholder  empowerment  resulting  from  the  project’s  institutional  and  capacity-building 
interventions.  The  project  will  instill  among  the  stakeholders  a  sense  of  accountability  in 
sustaining and managing the local natural resource base. Analysis of representative investment 
models generated economic internal rates of return greater than the opportunity cost threshold 
of 12%, confirming that the project is economically viable.PF
